The procedures must include the operating limits for the process, the consequences of deviations from those operating limits, and steps required to correct or avoid deviations.  The procedures must also include the hazards presented by the chemicals, the procedures, controls, and personnel protective equipment to limit exposure, measures to be taken if contact occurs, quality control and inventory control of raw materials, and any other unique hazards.

These procedures must be readily available to the employees who work in or maintain the process.  The procedures shall be updated regularly to such that they are maintained current.  Annually the procedures will be certified as current and accurate.

Control over access to PSM/RMP-covered areas must be maintained only to those required.

A list of the Palmetto Pedic written operating procedures related to the jobs which are considered PSM/RMP covered procedures, are kept by the Maintenance Manager.  These procedures will be developed to include all the information required to meet the standard.  To ensure that all PSM/RMP-related information is contained the procedure, an operating procedure checklist for PSM/RMP certification (Attachment 4-1) is to be used for each PSM/RMP-covered operating procedure.  This checklist will be completed during procedure development and review.

Section 1
Applicability
1.1	Purpose
The purpose of this section is to provide a mechanism to identify the processes at the Palmetto Pedic facility that are covered by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) and to provide documentation for their determination.
1.2	Regulatory Overview
The Risk Management Plan (RMP) applicability requirements can be found in EPA 40 CFR 68. The programs contain requirements for preventing or minimizing the consequences of catastrophic releases of toxic, reactive, flammable, or explosive chemicals.  These releases may result in toxic, fire, or explosion hazards.

This procedure applies to all processes and facility operations at the Palmetto Pedic facility that meet the following criteria:

¿	A process that involves a chemical at or above the specified threshold quantities listed in 40 CFR 68.130; and
¿	A process that involves a flammable liquid or gas (warranting an NFPA 4 rating) on-site in one location, in a quantity of 10,000 pounds (4,535.9 kg) or more except for:
¿	Hydrocarbon fuels used solely for workplace consumption as a fuel (e.g., propane used for comfort heating, gasoline for vehicle refueling), if such fuels are not a part of a process containing another highly hazardous chemical covered by this standard.
1.3	Procedure
1.3.1	Process Safety Management
Any new material introduced to the facility must go through a chemical approval process. As part of this process there is a determination whether the chemical is listed as under the PSM/RMP regulations or if it is flammable under the OSHA/EPA definitions.  If the chemical is identified as a PSM or RMP chemical, then its use in the process is reviewed to determine if due to the quantity on-site and the process configuration if the process will be considered covered under the PSM/RMP regulations. To facilitate this, a list of covered chemicals is provided in Attachment 1-1 (please consult the OSHA/EPA website for the most up to date

damage to equipment would occur that could jeopardize the integrity of related equipment. Lists of the safe limits on process parameters can be found in Attachment 2-4 of this manual.

2.3.3	Process Safety Management Equipment Information
A list of all PSM/RMP-related equipment is shown on the P&IDs referenced in Attachment 2-2.  The equipment records are a function of the specific PSM/RMP equipment installed.  Ultimately, the PSM/RMP implementation team is responsible to ensure that the equipment PSI for that covered process is maintained.

¿	P & IDs - P & IDs are key documents that are necessary to conduct a PHA. They also are useful in preparing for determination of the mechanical integrity (MI) of process equipment.  Attachment 2-2 includes all the P & IDs relevant to this process.
¿	Electrical classification - No covered chemical is considered flammable; therefore, electrical classification is not required. 
¿	Ventilation system design - Ventilation is provided for the enclosed area, the process building, by roof mounted HVAC equipment and wall vents.

¿	Safety systems - Safety systems can be found as indicated on the P&ID drawings contained in Attachment 2-2.

Section 3
Process Hazard Analysis

The purpose of this section is to establish the procedures used to conduct PHA's of RMP-covered processes and the subsequent follow up of items identified by the PHA's as having a

list).  Attachment 1-2 contains a site-specific listing of the covered processes at the Palmetto Pedic facility.
1.3.2	Process Safety Management Program Development
Should a new PSM/RMP chemical and covered process be identified, then a PSM/RMP program will be developed for that process.  The PSM/RMP Committee for a new process will be formed to develop the PSM/RMP elements of the new covered process.  

 
Section 2
Process Safety Information
2.1	Purpose
The purpose of this section is to establish the location of the information required to be compiled for compliance with this regulation and to establish the responsibilities for maintaining this data.  The data is used to identify and understand the hazards posed by those processes involving highly hazardous chemicals.
2.2	Regulatory Review
The PSI program requirements can be found in EPA 40 CFR 68.65.  The regulation requires that specified PSI be compiled prior to performing a PHA (see Section 3).  The following information must be maintained:
2.2.1	Chemical Information
Information pertaining to the hazards of the regulated substances in the process consisting of at least:
¿	Toxicity information
¿	Permissible exposure limits
¿	Physical data
¿	Reactivity data
¿	Corrosivity data
¿	Thermal and chemical stability data
¿	Hazardous effects of inadvertent mixing of different materials that could foreseeably occur.
2.2.2	Process Technology
Information concerning the technology of the process shall include at least the following:
¿	Block flow diagram or simplified process flow diagram
¿	Process chemistry
¿	Maximum intended inventory
¿	Safe upper and lower limits for such items as temperatures, pressures, flows or composition.
¿	Evaluation of the consequences of deviations
Where the original technical information no longer exists, such information may be developed in conjunction with the process hazards analysis in sufficient detail to support the analysis.
2.2.3	Process Equipment
Information pe

rtaining to the equipment in the process shall include:
¿	Materials of construction
¿	Piping & instrument diagrams (P&IDs)
¿	Electrical classification
¿	Relief system design and design basis
¿	Ventilation system design
¿	Design codes and standards employed.
¿	Material and energy balances 
¿	Safey systems
2.3	Procedure
The following subsections identify the locations of information required by this procedure and the means used to keep that information current.  The covered processes are identified in Attachment 1-2.
2.3.1	Chemical Information
The chemical information required is included in the Safety Data Sheets (SDS) for the hazardous materials that are used at Palmetto Pedic.  A copy of all SDS used in the plant are contained at the following locations:

¿	Documentation Storage Area

SDS are filed alphabetically by where the chemical is used and by the chemical's name.  The Human Resource Department controls distribution, availability, and accuracy of information.  SDS for the PSM/RMP covered chemicals are included as Attachment 2-6.
2.3.2	Process Technology Information
The technology information records are a function of the specific PSM/RMP process. Ultimately, the PSM/RMP committee is responsible to ensure that the PSI for that covered process is maintained.  

¿	Block flow diagram - Block flow diagrams for the covered processes are contained in Attachment 2-1 of this manual.  Details from process specific P & ID's provide additional information.  A list of these drawings is found in Attachment 2-2 of this manual.
¿	Process chemistry - Process chemistry information can be found in Attachment 2-3.
¿	Maximum intended inventory - A summary of the maximum intended inventory for each covered substance is contained in Attachment 2-4 of this manual.
¿	Safe upper and lower limits for process parameters - Safe upper and lower limits for process parameters, such as temperature, pressure, flow, and composition refer to those limits outside of which

significant risk as required by United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) and OSHA.
3.2	Regulatory Overview
PHA requirements can be found in EPA 40 CFR 68.67.  

A PHA must be conducted on all the PSM/RMP-covered processes.  A PHA is an organized and systematic effort to identify and analyze the significance of potential hazards associated with the processing or handling of highly hazardous chemicals.  The PHA will identify and evaluate the hazards of the process and make recommendations on measures to control the hazards of the process.  One of the following methods to evaluate the process will be utilized:
¿	What-If
¿	Checklist
¿	What-If/Checklist
¿	Hazards and operability study (HAZOP)
¿	Failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA)
¿	Fault tree analysis
¿	An appropriate equivalent methodology

Each PHA shall address the following:
¿	Hazards of process
¿	Previous incidents
¿	Engineering and administrative controls	
¿	Consequences of control failures


An individual knowledgeable in the PHA process must lead the PHA team.  The team must also include members with engineering and operations expertise in the RMP-covered process.

A system must be in place to prioritize the findings and recommendations of the team and address the recommendations in a timely manner.  The actions taken to address the recommendations must be documented.  PHA's must be updated or revalidated every five years and retained for the life of the process.
3.3	Procedure
3.3.1	Procedural Steps
PHA's will be initiated and performed as process changes occur or as required by the revalidation process.  The PSM/RMP Committee will make a recommendation on the format for the PHA to the PSM/RMP Coordinator for approval.

Prior to the PHA, the PHA team will confirm that the necessary process information has been assembled.  The PSM/RMP Coordinator will notify the production area supervisor, other personnel, of any missing information prior to beginning the PHA.  The info

rmation must include the following:
¿	Updated PSI as identified in Section 2.
¿	Information on previous PSM/RMP incidents as identified in Section 6.
¿	Any other information deemed necessary to perform an adequate review.
3.3.2	Scope of Process Hazard Analysis
The PHA must address and document the following:
¿	Hazards of Process
The hazards of concern are those that could lead to releases of toxic chemicals, fires, or explosions, which could potentially have a catastrophic consequence within the plant.  Process hazards will be evaluated during the PHA based on the nature of the chemicals involved (such as toxicity, flammability, etc.), the process conditions (i.e., flow, temperature, pressure, and composition), the team's experience, and the information about previous incidents in the plant (and/or at other sites).  Hazards associated with non-routine operations (such as startup, shutdown, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, and temporary operations, if any) will also be studied.
¿	Previous Incidents
Any past incidents or near misses that had a likely potential for catastrophic release of a highly hazardous chemical should be identified and discussed by the PHA team.  Prior to the PHA study, relevant incident investigation reports filed within the past five years should be collected to prepare a list of past incidents and near misses that had a potential for catastrophic consequences.  These incidents will then be analyzed during the study to evaluate the findings as well as the originally suggested remedies.
¿	Engineering and Administrative Controls
The engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards and their interrelationships will be addressed during the PHA and documented under safeguards as existing safeguards in the worksheets. Such controls include appropriate application of detection methodologies to provide early warning of releases; inventory reduction; substitution of less hazardous materials; protective systems such

as deluges, monitors, foams; criteria for equipment spacing; pressure relief valves; interlocks; and redundancy in instrumentation.
¿	Consequences of Control Failures
The most severe consequences of the sequential events for any identified deviations without taking credit for existing safeguards (i.e., assuming all safeguards fail) will be discussed by the PHA team and documented under consequences in the worksheets. Such consequences, associated with failure of engineering and administrative controls, may result in the release of hazardous chemicals, which may result in the following:
¿	Potential personnel injury
¿	Equipment damage or loss of equipment
¿	Loss of plant
¿	Loss of production
¿	Impacts on public safety.
¿	Environmental impacts
¿	Operability problems

Consequences discussed during the study will be limited to employee protection and protection of the environment.  For deviations potentially resulting in significant consequences, the team should consider the need for specific and reliable safeguards.  Palmetto Pedic uses a matrix approach to determine the priority to be placed on an action associated with each failure event. The priority is based on the severity of the consequences of a particular failure and the likelihood that an event will take place.  The matrix will result in a priority ranking for recommendations associated with each failure resulting in recommendations. The matrix will be developed by the PHA team and agreed upon prior to the start of the PHA. The matrix will be documented in the PHA report.
3.3.3	Process Hazard Analysis Documentation and Follow-up
PHA action items and follow-up recommendations will be tracked using spreadsheets.  The spreadsheets will be reviewed during the quarterly PSM/RMP Committee meetings.  The PHA scribe will complete the PHA report.  When completed, the report will be forwarded to PSM/RMP Committee, who will utilize the prioritization of the improvement recommendations to initiate the approp

riate actions to respond to each of the recommendations.  This may include a request for engineering, completion of a work request, or a decision that a particular recommendation will not be implemented.  The team also will designate a responsible individual for follow-up on the action and an anticipated completion date of the actions.  The actions associated with each PHA recommendation will be documented and tracked by the PSM/RMP Coordinator.  The documentation associated with the PHA will be retained for the life of the process by the PSM/RMP Coordinator.
3.3.4	Communication to Affected Employees
Interactive communication is required for communicating PHA findings and recommendations to affected employees.  PHA information is communicated to the affected employees during monthly safety meetings.  Department safety teams, environmental health and safety (EHS) personnel, and the PSM/RMP committee also will be available to assist with communications as required.
3.3.5	Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation
The PHA will be revalidated every five years following the initial completion of the initial PHA.  Documentation of the revalidation will be retained for life of the process.  The process safety implementation team will initiate this revalidation.  The original PHA will be reviewed to assure that nothing has changed.  The team will look at all incidents that have occurred in the previous five years and changes made to the process and procedures.  This revalidation may result in a new list of recommendations that will require that action, follow-up, and communication have occurred in the previous five years and changes made to the process and procedures.   
Section 4
Operating Procedures
4.1	Purpose
The purpose of this section is to establish the process for developing, and maintaining the operating procedures used for PSM/RMP-related equipment and processes.
4.2	Regulatory Overview
The RMP operating procedure requirements can be found in EPA 40 CFR 68.69.

ial start-up procedures will be used for start-ups that occur after a shutdown or emergency, therefore only one procedure will be maintained.

Additional safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations will be developed and implemented.  These safe work practices shall apply to employees and contractor employees and consist of the following:

¿	Lockout/tagout
¿	Confined space entry 
¿	Opening process equipment or piping 
4.3.1	Procedure Maintenance & Availability

Procedures, once developed and approved, are maintained in the Maintenance Manager.  All plant operators have access to these procedures.  The procedures are certified that they are complete and accurate on an annual basis by the management team.
4.3.2	Area Access Control

The plant maintains overall access control. All outside individuals are required to follow specific visitor requirements.

All employees are trained on the hazards of the chemicals through the OSHA Hazard Communication (HAZCOM) program.  Visitors can only enter the facility when escorted by Palmetto Pedic personnel trained to work in the area. 
Section 5
Operator Training
5.1	Purpose
The purpose of this section is to describe the facility's approach to providing operator training and documentation requirements.
5.2	Regulatory Overview
The RMP operating procedure requirements can be found in EPA 40 CFR 68.71. The PSM/RMP regulations require that the employer provide operator training that includes both initial and refresher training, as well as training certification.  The training must include specific health and safety hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices.  Initial training must occur before assignment.  Refresher training must be provided at least every three years, more frequently if determined by operators.  All documentation of training must describe the means used to verify understanding, which can be an observation of work tasks, a written test, a description of an

operating procedure, or other means.
5.3	Procedure
5.3.1	Initial Training
Extensive on-the-job training of new employees is conducted when an employee is assigned to a production area to work with hazardous chemicals.  A position analysis worksheet is prepared for each process operator position.  The position analysis worksheet provides a list of the essential duties and responsibilities that are required for the position.  Employees are required to demonstrate competence in these areas prior to working without supervision.  

Additionally, through its HAZCOM program, Palmetto Pedic trains its operators in the proper handling of hazardous chemicals specific to their Department, proper operation of the process, use of safety equipment required for their work, and their responsibilities in the case of an emergency.  
5.3.2	Refresher Training

Refresher training is conducted every three years, at a minimum.  
5.3.3	Training Documentation
Documentation of all training is maintained in the Human Resources Manager's office.

 
Section 6
Incident Investigation
6.1	Purpose
The purpose of this section is to describe Palmetto Pedic's approach to evaluating significant events that did or could have resulted in a catastrophic release of a hazardous chemical.
6.2	Regulatory Overview
Incident investigation requirements can be found in EPA 40 CFR 68.81. The incident investigation program requires investigations of incidents or near misses involving actual or potential catastrophic releases begin within 48 hours. The employer is required to assemble an incident investigation team, investigate incidents, document findings, and track resolution of action items from the investigations.  If an incident involved a contractor, a contractor employee must be a participant on the team.  Incident reports must be retained for five years.
6.3	Procedure
6.3.1	Incident Identification
All significant events will be immediately reported to the Production Area Supervisor and

an injury/incident investigation will begin.  The Production Supervisor will start an Incident Investigation Report and assign an investigation team.  If a PSM/RMP incident or near miss is identified, the PSM/RMP Committee will be designated to the incident investigation team.
6.3.2	Incident Investigation
The incident investigation team will initiate the investigation within 48 hours of the incident.  The incident investigation team will add any individuals required to the team for the purposes of performing a thorough investigation.  This may include contractors, vendors, engineers, corporate specialists, etc.  The incident investigation team will evaluate the causes of the incident.  A report will be generated identifying the necessary follow-up actions, individuals responsible for the follow-up actions, and a proposed time frame to complete follow-up. 

6.3.3	Process Safety Management Incident Investigation Documentation and Follow-up
The incident investigation team will complete the incident investigation report.  The team will initiate the appropriate actions to respond to each of the recommendations.  The actions associated with each finding will be documented and tracked by the PSM/RMP Coordinator.  Progress addressing the incident findings will be forwarded to the Production Supervisor and Plant Manager, as appropriate.  A report summarizing the status of the findings will be generated by the PSM/RMP Coordinator.  The documentation associated with the incident findings will be retained for five years.
6.3.4	Communication to Affected Employees
Interactive communication is required for communicating incident investigation findings and recommendations to affected employees. The results of the incident investigation communicated to the affected employees during the monthly safety meeting.  Department safety teams, EHS personnel, and the PSM/RMP implementation team also will be available to assist with communications, as required. 
Section 7
Compliance A

udits
7.1	Purpose
The objective of Palmetto Pedic's PSM/RMP compliance audit program is to review the PSM/RMP program to ensure it is adequate, and the procedures developed for compliance are being followed.
7.2	Regulatory Overview
The RMP compliance audit procedure requirements can be found in EPA 40 CFR 68.79. The PSM/RMP regulations require that each PSM/RMP program be audited for compliance with the regulation at least every 3 years. This recertification will verify that the procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being followed. The compliance audit must be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process, and a report of the findings of the audit must be developed and documented noting deficiencies that will be corrected.  The employer shall promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit and document that deficiencies have been corrected.  The two most recent audits must be kept on file.
7.3	Procedure
7.3.1	Scope of the Audit Program
For the purposes of this program, the scope is limited solely toward compliance with the PSM/RMP rule.  
7.3.2	Frequency of Audits
Compliance audits will be conducted every three years to verify that the     procedures and practices developed for the affected facility are adequate and are being followed.
7.3.3	Staffing for Audits
The audit team selected will include at least one person knowledgeable in the process.   Team members will be chosen for their experience, knowledge, and training and should be familiar with the processes and auditing techniques, practices, and procedures.  The size of the team will be determined based on the size and complexity of the process to be audited.  The audit may be performed by a third-party or internally, based on Palmetto Pedic's desire.
7.3.4	Audit Reporting
The final audit report will be generated by the audit team within 21 days of completion of the audit.  At a minimum, it

will contain the following items:
¿	Identification of the process/facility being audited.
¿	The purpose of the audit
¿	The names, titles, and affiliations of the members of the audit team
¿	The date of the audit
¿	The specific PSM/RMP elements and supporting documents, etc. that are the subject of the audit.
¿	A summary listing of findings
¿	A listing of those individuals/departments to which the audit report is distributed.
7.3.5	Process Safety Management Audit Documentation and Follow-up
The audit team will complete the audit report.  When completed, the report will be forwarded to the PSM/RMP Committee, who will initiate the appropriate actions to respond to each of the recommendations.  The PSM/RMP implementation team also will designate a responsible individual for follow-up on the action and an anticipated completion date of the actions.  The actions associated with each audit finding will be documented and tracked.  Progress on addressing the audit findings also will be discussed during the quarterly PSM/RMP Committee meetings.  The documentation associated with the audit findings will be retained for the life of the process.
